pullRequest.body:
Define the notion of measure-dense family in a measure space, and the notion of separable measure. Prove that if a measure is separable and E is a second-countable `NormedAddCommGroup`, then the corresponding Lp space is second-countable. True in particular when the measurable space is countably generated and the measure is s-finite.

---

It looks like you could use [MeasureTheory.Measure.FiniteSpanningSetsIn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Measure/Typeclasses.html#MeasureTheory.Measure.FiniteSpanningSetsIn) (the sequence of sets there is not monotone but you can take the union of the n first sets).
Thank you for the tip!

We have a specific meaning for `MeasureSpace` in mathlib: it is a measurable space endowed with a canonical measure, called `volume`. This is not what you are speaking about, so your name should not mention `MeasureSpace`. As it's a property of the measure, it should also start with `Is` if possible. What about `IsCountablySeparated`, for instance?

I am a bit reluctant to use "separated" when talking about separability because I find it confusing with the notion of separation, e.g. [MeasurableSpace.SeparatesPoints](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/MeasurableSpace/CountablyGenerated.html#MeasurableSpace.SeparatesPoints). Maybe I can use `IsSeparable`? This is no longer used in #12394, it was replaced by `IsSeparablySupported`. Tell me what you think.
ok for `IsSeparable`!
Is it possible to weaken `SigmaFinite` to `SFinite` here?

I don't think so. Consider the infinite sum of the Lebesgue measure on $[0,1]$. Then $\mathcal{A}$ is measure-dense if for any measurable set $s$ there exists $t \in \mathcal{A}$ such that $\lambda(s \Delta t) = 0$. Now consider countable unions of intervals of the form $[1/(n+1), 1/n]$. This gives an uncountable family $\mathcal{B}$ of measurable sets such that the symmetric difference of two of those sets is positive (so infinite in this case). Moreover if $\lambda(s \Delta t) = 0$ and $\lambda(s \Delta s') = \infty$ then $\lambda(s' \Delta t) = \infty$, so $t \in \mathcal{A}$ can only approximate at most one set in $\mathcal{B}$, thus $\mathcal{A}$ cannot be countable.

Doesn't measure-dense only require approximation for finite-measure sets? In your example, all the sets have infinite measure, so they wouldn't need to be approximated by elements of \mathcal{A}, right?
Woops sorry I had forgotten my own definition!

Ok after digging the internet I think I managed to prove it but it is not straight-forward: $\mu$ can be written $\mu = \mu_{sf} + \mu_{0-\infty}$, where $\mu_{sf}$ is semi-finite (any set with infinite measure has a subset with positive finite measure) and $\mu_{0-\infty}$ takes values $0$ or $\infty$. $\mu_{0-\infty}$ is separable. If $\mu$ is s-finite, then $\mu_{sf}$ is still s-finite I think (we remove the support of $\mu_{0-\infty}$), and then I think a measure which is both s-finite and semi-finite is $\sigma$-finite, because it is equivalent to a probability measure and its density (which I think exists not by radon-nikodym but something else) has to be finite everywhere, therefore it is separable. The sum of two separable measures is separable. I am not totally sure, I have never manipulated s-finite and semi-finite measures before.
I did not manage to do the proof directly however, and it looks like semi-finite measures are not in Mathlib yet.

I even think we can prove that separable measures on a countably-generated space are exactly measures which are the sum of a $\sigma$-finite measure and a $(0-\infty)$-measure.

I have on a branch that every s-finite measure can be written as the sum of a sigma-finite measure and a measure which takes only values 0 and infinity. I will be PRing it in the coming days.
However I am also busy with other things and if you wait for my result it will probably delay this PR by at least a week.

Oh nice! I don't know what @sgouezel thinks, the goal of this PR was mostly second-countability of basic Lp spaces (so with Lebesgue measure), so I think I can add the generalization to s-finite measures in a future PR.
It can definitely wait for an improvement to S-finite measures in a future PR. Maybe add a TODO about this?
Done!

In fact #12759 has already been merged, and I think it contains everything you need to extend your result to s-finite measures (see in particular the instance saying that `SigmaFinite (Î¼.restrict Î¼.sigmaFiniteSet)`, and `measure_eq_zero_or_top_of_subset_compl_sigmaFiniteSet`).
Thanks, I'll look into it.
I added the generalization to s-finite measures!

```suggestion
  -- `1 â‰¤ p` so `p â‰  0`, we prove it now as it is often needed.
```
Is there a reason why you are using a real number instead of an ennreal here? Since everything happens in ennreal, it would seem more natural.

I did it this way because it felt more natural because on the paper $\epsilon$ is rarely infinite. If I make it an ennreal it will maybe simplify calculations, but also add a case because I can't deal with it the same way if it is infinite. I'll try so see what I get.

I tried to use an ennreal or an nnreal, but I don't think it's a good idea. A real epsilon is useful because I use it to do real analysis. If it is ennreal, I don't have a metric space. If it is nnreal, then it's the same as using a real, because I can't lift the measure, otherwise it loses its properties (at least I don't know how to do it).

```suggestion
      { set := Î¼.toFiniteSpanningSetsIn.set
        set_mem := fun n â†¦ self_subset_generateSetAlgebra (ð’œ := ð’œ) <| Or.inr âŸ¨n, rflâŸ©
        finite := Î¼.toFiniteSpanningSetsIn.finite
        spanning := Î¼.toFiniteSpanningSetsIn.spanning }
```

```suggestion
instance [CountablyGenerated X] [SFinite Î¼] : IsSeparable Î¼ where
```
No need to name the instances in general. Same thing below.

```suggestion
    refine âŸ¨â„¬, count_ð’œ.image (fun s â†¦ s âˆ© Î¼.sigmaFiniteSet), ?_, ?_âŸ©
```
`refine` can already be used to split your goal in several subgoals when needed.

```suggestion
s-finite), if `E` is a second-countable `NormedAddCommGroup`, and if `1 â‰¤ p < +âˆž`,
```

When a goal is trivial like that, you can deal with it right away in the calling line, i.e., use
```
    refine Lp.induction p_ne_top.elim (P := fun f â†¦ f âˆˆ closure D) ?_ ?_ isClosed_closure
```
above.

No need to intro it, as the next line will remove it anyway.
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
theorem Measure.measureDens.fin_meas (hð’œ : Î¼.MeasureDense ð’œ) :
```

```suggestion
lemma fin_meas_approx_of_measureDense (hð’œ : Î¼.MeasureDense ð’œ) {s : Set X}
```
```suggestion
lemma Measure.MeasureDense.fin_meas_approx (hð’œ : Î¼.MeasureDense ð’œ) {s : Set X}
```
etc

```suggestion
theorem Measure.MeasureDense.of_generateFrom_isSetAlgebra_finite [IsFiniteMeasure Î¼] (hð’œ : IsSetAlgebra ð’œ)
```

One cheeky way to do this with a single `Fact` is to assume instead `Fact (1 â‰¤ p.toReal)`, which works since `âˆž.toReal = 0`. I *think* we use this in other places, but I can't remember for sure right now. If we do, that might be a reason to do it here. If we don't, then we shouldn't do it here either.

I have never seen it, and `grep` does not find it either (not as a `Fact` instance I mean). I wrote it this way myself to be consistent with [MeasureTheory.Lp.induction](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/SimpleFuncDenseLp.html#MeasureTheory.Lp.induction), though in this cases the `p â‰  âˆž` hypothesis is not an instance.

Is this better? In some sense, it's morally a weaker assumption (even though they are equivalent given the other assumptions on `E`), especially because type class inference only has an instance in the second countable â†’ separable direction.
```suggestion
instance [IsSeparable Î¼] [TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace E] : SecondCountableTopology (Lp E p Î¼) := by
```
You're absolutely right!

You keep saying this, but I don't see it *explicitly* anywhere in this PR. However, (a) it's true not just for `LÂ¹`, but for `Láµ–` more generally, right? And (b), I think this is essentially proved in part of the `Lp.induction` step in the second countability instance. So, I think it makes sense to factor that out as a lemma.

I added `Measure.MeasureDense.indicatorConstLp_subset_closure`, which indeed factors out a part of the computations, tell me if it satisfies you. I did not add an equivalent result for separability because it seemed less useful, but tell me if I should add it.

I haven't tried to do this myself yet, but it feels to me like there should be some sort of more general statement that is easier to prove. Maybe something like a (countable) sum of separable measures is separable (is that true?); if so, then that would imply this easily.

I tried to prove that a sum of separable measures is separable when @sgouezel suggested to generalize from sigma-finite to s-finite measures, but failed spectacularly, and so went for this less direct proof. I did not even manage to prove that the sum of two separable measures is separable. I do not claim it is false since I wasn't able to find a counter example (this would involve separable measures which are not s-finite and I'm struggling to find one).

Here is a sketch of proof that the sum of two separable measures is separable (I haven't checked details, so this may be nonsense).

First, if mu is separable, consider the union `A mu` of the finite-measure sets in a countable measure-dense subset. On the set `A mu`, the measure `mu` is sigma-finite. And in the complement of `A mu`, every set has measure zero or infinity (otherwise, you could approximate such a set by a set in the measure-dense subset, which would then not be contained in `A mu`, contradiction). Moreover, the sigma-algebra on `A mu` is countably generated.

Suppose now mu and nu are separable. Then, on `A mu \cap A nu`, the measure mu + nu is sigma-finite, and the algebra is countably generated, so it is separable there. And on its complement, every set has measure zero or infinite, so won't be relevant for the approximation property.

(Note that this definitely isn't simpler than the current argument, so it doesn't really answer Jireh's question of a simple proof).

Thanks for your answer. I'm not sure this proof works though, for two reasons:
1. I don't see why the sigma-algebra on `A mu` is countably generated.
2. Even if we assume that the sigma-algebra is countably generated, there is a problem when we take `s` a subset of `(A mu) \ (A nu)`. If `nu s = 0`, then `(mu + nu) s` can have finite and non zero measure, so the argument does not work.

However, taking inspiration on this, if we assume that the sigma-algebra is compactly generated, I think it shows that separable measures are exactly the ones which can be written as the sum of a sigma-finite measure and a 0-infinity measure.

1. Morally, up to measure zero, everything is generated by intersections of sets in the two measure-dense countable sets, so it should be countably generated (well, this depends on the precise definition of countably generated, but I'm not expecting a real difficulty here).
2. You're absolutely right, I had overlooked this one. Here is a possible way out to deal with `(A mu) \ (A nu)`. Restricting to one of the sets in the measure-dense family, I will assume that mu is finite on `A mu`. Then I claim that there is a subset `B mu nu` of `A mu` on which `nu` is zero, and such that on its complement `mu + nu` is a zero-infinity measure. It's an instance of the Hahn decomposition, but simpler here as `nu` is already zero-infinity: just consider a subset of `A mu` of maximal `mu`-measure on which `nu` is zero. Then, on `B mu nu`, the measure `nu` is zero so one can use the measure-dense set of mu (intersected with `B mu nu`). While on `A mu \ B mu nu`, the measure `mu + nu` is zero-infinity, so there is nothing to be approximated.

This is getting more and more complicated, so it's probably not a good idea to try to formalize this since the version you have is already very satisfactory!

Here is some cool notation:
```suggestion
    { indicatorConstLp p hs hÎ¼s c | (s : Set X) (hs : MeasurableSet s) (hÎ¼s : Î¼ s â‰  âˆž) } âŠ†
    closure { indicatorConstLp p (hð’œ.measurable s hs) hÎ¼s c |
      (s : Set X) (hs : s âˆˆ ð’œ) (hÎ¼s : Î¼ s â‰  âˆž) } := by
```
